page.title: 03Ecology of Weston and Area
page.content:
Though cultivated, the area has plenty of trees and some large hedges which provide cover for wildlife. Little owls, tawny owls and sometimes long- eared owls breed locally. Deciduous trees in Weston Wood provide roosting and nesting ground for a colony of rooks and jackdaws. The old hazel coppice at Wormough is a haunt for chiff-chaffs and willow warblers and foxes and deer also find cover there. Kingfishers and green sandpipers are occasionally seen on stream banks and kestrels hover above the rough road- side vegetation in search of vermin.
Wormough is covered by primroses, bluebells and wood anemones in Spring. Rare orchids and other plants can be found in a few old meadows. Some 150 species of plants have been recorded along the railway wildlife sanctuary.
